items.title: Welcome!
items.content:
Welcome to Flatiron School! We're thrilled that you've joined our community of learners!

The following content is designed for passionate, curious, self-driven, and serious about learning. We are comrades in a never-ending quest for knowledge. While there are no shortcuts, we believe that you will learn quickly by providing knowledge in an optimized order, reinforcing knowledge with hands-on, feedback-driven practice, and providing space for discussion.

Our goal is to provide the right materials, support, and structure you need to discover your own love for designing outstanding products.

Pre-work is required to start at Flatiron School and you have access to this useful material even prior to applying. Please note some resources mentioned throughout are only available to enrolled students, such as community and technical coach support. 

If you’re just researching the programs, keep in mind that this is the same pre-course work admitted students are working through. Some of this information will seem granular, just work through as much as you can and know that you will have time to revisit content should you go through our admissions process.  

The Flatiron Community

We don't believe in learning alone. As you make progress, expect to bump into other learners just like you, ready and willing to help each other succeed. Together, we can go further than we could ever go alone. We expect everyone here to be friendly, respectful, helpful, and nice.

items.title: What is Canvas?
items.content:
Canvas is a learning platform used by universities and educational institutions across the country and the world. Flatiron School uses Canvas to deliver all curriculum content for your program.

Canvas is where all official Flatiron School communication, assignment submission, grading, attendance, etc., will take place for the entirety of your course. You should check Canvas multiple times a day for updates, announcements, assignments, and the day's schedule. Canvas hosts many features that you will become familiar with over your time with Flatiron School. The following lessons will introduce you to and explain some of these most important functions. You can also download the Canvas app from the App Store.

items.title: Navigating Canvas
items.content:
Dashboard - the first thing you see when you log into Canvas, the Dashboard gives a high level view of the courses in which you're enrolled. Your instructor will release new courses as you go through the program.

Global Navigation - static menu on the left side of the page and accessible from any page on Canvas, the Global Navigation gives you direct access to your courses and other information in Canvas.

Sidebar - found within each course, the Sidebar houses various features that allow access to the course materials.

View the video tutorial for more information on how to use Canvas effectively.

items.title: Lesson Types in Canvas
items.content:
COURSES

Your Flatiron School program is broken up into courses. Each course represents a section of our core curriculum. The Flatiron School course structure is something that we'll discuss in more detail in later lessons. For now, we'll discuss the content types you are likely to see in the Canvas platform.

MODULES

Flatiron School organizes content within courses by breaking them up into modules. The modules will control the entire course flow, and within them, you'll find all your lessons, labs, assignments, and quizzes for the course. Modules can hold several types of content:

  • Page: a page of content to read
  • Discussion: a course discussion in which teachers and students can actively participate
  • Quiz: A course quiz, generally multiple choice questions or true/false questions
  • Assignment: A course assignment. Assignments are graded projects that count toward your final score
  • Link or External Tool: an external link or tool to view information outside of the course
  • File: a file to download or view

You may be required to perform certain actions to complete a module. Requirements may include:

  • View: You must view the item.
  • Mark as done: You must mark the module item as done before progressing to the next item.
  • Contribute: You must post a reply to the discussion topic or contribute content to a page.
  • Submit: You must submit the assignment, graded discussion, or quiz.
  • Score at least X points: You must submit the assignment with a minimum of the shown score.

You can find the 'Modules' button on the sidebar on the left-hand side within each course.

ASSIGNMENTS

While the module controls the flow of the entire course, you can also access a running list of your course assignments via the 'Assignments' button on your Sidebar on the left-hand side within the course.

By default, assignments are grouped by overdue assignments, upcoming assignments, undated assignments, and past assignments.

Each assignment includes an icon designating an assignment, discussion, or quiz and will also display availability dates, due dates, and the number of points the assignment is worth.

You can find the 'Assignments' button on the sidebar on the left-hand side within each course.

items.title: Introduction to Tools
items.content:
Product Designers, UX Designers, and UI Designers use a variety of tools.

In the last year, more companies have allowed employees to work from home. This has created a need for design and prototyping tools with better collaboration support. For this course, we consult the most current version of the UX Tools Survey. The survey includes insights from over 4000 design practitioners from around the world to see how industry tools change from year to year. You can read through the survey to identify other tools to experiment within your design practice, but this course has elected to primarily use Figma, Invision, and Webflow as the foundations for production work in all phases.

These tools are robust and serve the needs of UX and UI professionals to create low-fidelity mockups, high-fidelity mockups, and clickable prototypes for testing. In this prework course, we will get you set up with these tools and give you a brief walkthrough of the core features you'll need for Design Labs. We will not take a deep dive into all the features of these tools in the prework. Your instructors in the main coursework will walk you through special case scenarios and additional features to speed up workflows.

Continue on to get set up with Figma and practice some basic layout and prototyping features.

items.title: What is Product Design?
items.content: Distinguishing Product Design from UX Design can be difficult since the skills and processes they employ are similar. However, when considering the entire life cycle of a product, the true nature of the Product Designer is revealed. In this video, we talk about the considerations and context of Product Design, UX Design, and UI Design to clarify how we define the terms and the roles these designers play in the creation of new products and the maintenance of existing products.

items.title: Product Design and McDonalds
items.content: The McDonald Brothers innovated the restaurant business with SpeeDee system. It allowed them to create a consistent product much faster than their competition and changed the nature of food service forever. In this video, we discuss the methods that the McDonald brothers used to create their system and how those practices align with Product Design.

items.title: A Note Taking App
items.content: In this video, we explore the initial research and thought process that goes into conceiving a product that has a market fit. We explore the idea of creating a Note-taking app and compare the potential competing apps. We do all of this to understand how a Product Designer, UX Designer, and UI Designer could contribute to this process in different ways.

items.title: Design Lab: Grocery List App
items.content: In this video, we set up the Grocery List App Design Lab and talk through an approach to completing both parts of the assignment.

items.title: What is User Experience Design?
items.content: In this video, we discuss a general UX process that is employed by UX Designers and Product Designers to uncover user needs and market potential for products.

items.title: Design Lab: Agency UX Process
items.content:
UX Agency Processes

UX agencies are companies that work with brands to solve UX problems. They are experts in the UX process and serve companies that want to improve on products and create valuable user experiences.

In this activity, explore three UX agency websites to investigate how they lay out their UX process. No two consultancy/agencies are exactly alike and they talk about their process in different ways. Think about what they are trying to convey with their process description and how it maps back to the three general phases of the UX process: Research, Ideation, and Testing. While investigating the following agency process, take notes of the similarities between the process and the differences.

** This page links to three agencies, but feel free to review agencies other than those listed here. 

Instrument

The instrument is a design-centric firm that offers many services. Highly regarded for their work with Nike, Levi, and Pinterest.

IDEO

IDEO is a world-renowned design agency that has worked with some of the largest brands in the world. IDEO has innovated in the UX design space and has been a steadfast thought-leader for generations of designers. They are a company to watch and follow. Look for the slideshow titled "How We Work" to see their process

Backen&Baeck

Backen&Baeck is an international Product Design company that takes a creative and informed approach to innovate products that are both practical and elegant

 

To complete this design lab, you should:

1. Investigate three agency websites to read about their work and process. Take notes about the agencies in a deck or document

2. Compare and contrast the ways that agencies think about their UX/UI process and note the similarities and difference

3. Think about how the processes explained on the agency sites related to our simple models around the UX process (Research/Ideation/Testing & the Double Diamond Framework)

items.title: Design Lab: Product Concepts for Developing Markets
items.content:
Project Outline

This project requires you to review market research related to food production in emerging markets. The paper does an excellent job of conveying the circumstances of farmers and households in rural communities and the troubles they face around industrialization. The goal of the research is to help improve the lives of farmers and the communities they serve. Your job is to read through the research and findings and create product concepts that will help farmers and producers navigate a changing economy. This project may include additional research on your part.

 

Download the market research here:

Marketing Research for Food Products in Developing Countries - IDL-9543.pdf

 

Things to consider

  1. This research paper is from the 1980s and doesn't talk about modern technology like smartphones and the internet. For the purposes of this project, you should pretend that the paper discussed modern-day emerging markets that have modern technology like computers and smartphones. Your product ideas should be software solutions, not industrial solutions. In the video, I laid out some possible product ideas that you might consider. You are free to use those ideas or to develop your own.
  2. This is your first time jumping into the Product Design process. I know that it can be intimidating to be asked to create solutions to complex problems. Remember, this is mostly a thought exercise. There are no wrong answers! You should try your best to be creative and to look for problems that resonate with you in the case studies.
  3. Try to develop two completely different solutions to different problems. For instance, if your first problem solves the issue of access to credit, your second solution should solve a different problem.
  4. This project is intentionally open-ended. You are not required to follow any best practices in terms of processes or deliverables. You are free to work with a pen and paper, or with Google docs, or with any other documentation method that is accessible to you.
  5. Have fun! This is your first dive into an incredible career, so make the most of it

 

Project Requirements

  1. Read through the research of food production in emerging markets
    Make sure you read through part one of the paper because it represents the bulk of the overall research and outlines the diagrams of traditional agricultural economies and the emerging economies that include industrialization. The problems studied are outlined in part one as well as methodology. It's a good example of excellent research.
    Also, be sure to find case studies that resonate with and inspire you to find solutions.
  2. Identify problems to solve
    After you've read through the research, document the problems that you want to solve. You don't have to be extremely specific, but you should indicate three things: The cause of the problems, the persons impacted by the problem, and any existing solutions to the problem
  3. Ideate possible solutions to the problems
    Try not to be critical of your ideas. It can be hard to trust your instincts. List out as many ideas as you can think of. Think about what technologies you could use (Phones, tablets, computers) and how you would implement a solution. Who else would be involved? What would it cost? What kind of training would the rural populations require? Be creative. The sky is the limit, but be sure to indicate solutions to both problems.
  4. Reduce your list of ideas to just the best solutions
    Even if you developed a hundred ideas in step 3, you can only implement one solution for each problem. Now is the time to be critical and cut out ideas that are impractical or might require more effort than they are worth. Find the best solution to each of your problems and start a document for each problem that explains why your solution makes sense.
  5. Create a project plan
    In the final step of this process, you will elaborate on each of your problem docs to indicate all of the considerations of a Product Designer. The following list isn't intended to be exhaustive. Try to think about all of the hurdles that you might face while developing your product.
    Consider the following questions:
    1. What further research is needed?
    2. What kind of prototype might make sense?
    3. Should you consult with other specialists?
    4. How will you conduct testing?
    5. What other hurdles might there be to success?
    6. Once the product is launched, how will you maintain it?

 

Keep your product ideas. After you've completed the Flatiron Product Design program, you can look back at this project and reevaluate your choices. It will be a good indicator of how far you've come in just a few months.

Good Luck!

items.title: The Role of Critique in Learning
items.content:
The fastest way to improve as a designer is to present your work to others and invite criticism. This can be an emotional exercise for new designers. We will encourage you to be bold and present your work, early and often, in this program. During the program, you will need to practice communicating your design work, whether verbally or through reports and presentations. You will not only be able to level up faster, but you will also stand out as a candidate during job interviews. 

You can prepare for this by reading, How to Survive a Critique: A Guide to Giving and Receiving Feedback, by AIGA. 

You'll also provide feedback on others' design work To help you build this skill, read Asynchronous Design Critique: Giving Feedback, by A List Apart. 

Finally, watch Julia Kestner's presentation on how her team turned a bad critique experience into "everyone's happy place."

And if you want to see how a product design team approaches a critique session, watch Figma's live critique session.

items.title: Next Steps
items.content:
Congratulations!

You have completed the prework for Product Design. We encourage you to continue playing with Figma and Invision to hone your skills with those two tools. We also encourage you to engage with admissions if you have any questions about the activities in prework. Remember this is just the first step in a lifelong journey of discovery and creativity. We can't wait to see you in the classroom. :)
